EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Harcros Chemicals Inc. (Harcros) has a long-standing commitment to safety and protection of the environment.  As members of the National Association of Chemical Distributors we adhere to the principals of Responsible Distribution and are committed to operating in a safe and responsible manner.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Harcros acquired this facility and its employees from Lynx Chemical Group in July 2007.  This facility is located on a 27-acre site and primarily manufactures sodium glucoheptonate and blends chemical formulations.



The two chemicals covered by the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule 40 CFR 68 are anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia.  A third RMP chemical was discontinued in 2015, which uses phosphorus trichloride, a toxic chemical subject to the RMP regulations.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management system addresses each of the key features of a successful prevention program, as described below.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The Harcros Chemicals Dalton plant maintains a variety of technical documents that describe the chemicals and processes at our facility.  The documents are kept up to date and are available to all employees.  They address important process parameters such as operating limits for equipment, design basis and configuration of equipment, and physical properties and hazards of the chemicals used.



Chemical information is contained in Safety Data Sheets (SDS's).  Important process parameters are also documented and maintained.  Engineering design documents may include (1) operating limits, (2) block flow or simplified process flow diagrams, (3) process chemistry, (4) maximum intended inventories, (5) design basis and configuration, (6) piping and instrumentation d

iagrams, and (7) other information that is important for understanding the design intent, operating limits, and hazards of each process.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The Harcros Chemicals Dalton plant has a program for ensuring hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled.  A hazard and operability study (HAZOP) analysis is typically used for our process hazard analyses.  We update and revalidate each hazard analysis every five years or whenever a significant change is made.  The results and findings from these revalidation studies are documented, and recommendations are tracked until resolved.



OPERATING PROCEDURES

Our employees develop and maintain operating procedures that ensure the safe operation of the facility.  These procedures cover (1) startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) startup of a new or improved process.  Operating procedures are annually certified as accurate to ensure they are updated following process changes.



This plant uses a batch sheet system.  Batch sheets are the detailed operating instructions for making a batch of product.  They include process deviation codes describing the actions to take under various conditions (e.g. high temperature or pressure, loss of cooling).



TRAINING

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant trains all workers to safely and efficiently perform their tasks as per our training matrix.  Employees new to a process are provided basic training including (1) overview of process, (2) properties of substances used and their associated hazards, and (3) a detailed review of the operating procedures.  Once they have demonstrated their understanding of the process, they are paired with an experienced operator to learn specific job functions and tasks.  After they demonstrate their competence in performing these tasks, they are allowed to work independently.



Refresher training intervals are decided, in part, by our employees b

ut are performed at least every three years.  All training is documented.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant maintains the mechanical integrity of our equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger employees, the public, or the environment.  Our inspection and testing program helps identify damage or deterioration before equipment fails.  When a problem is found, maintenance personnel correct the problem and try to identify the root causes to help prevent future problems.  Our quality assurance system ensures that new or replacement equipment meets the strict design standards for our facility.  The mechanical integrity system includes (1) inspection and testing procedures, (2) replacement equipment specifications, (3) procedures for safe work practices, (4) maintenance personnel training, and (5) required documentation.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Harcros reviews all changes to our processes to determine if new hazards are introduced or existing prevention measured are threatened.  Except for replacements-in-kind, all changes are subject to a hazard analysis to ensure that (1) new hazards are not inadvertently introduced, (2) safety consequences resulting from the change are addressed, (3) operators are notified of the change, and (4) training material, process safety information, and operating procedures are updated.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

For new processes and if a change requires updating the process safety information, we will perform a pre-startup safety review.  This review ensures that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are prepared for service before startup.  This review will generally include field verification of new construction and also serves as a quality assurance function by verifying that accident prevention measures are implemented correctly.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Employees at the Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant promptly investigate each incident that resulted in, or could have resu

lted in, serious injuries to employees, the public, or the environment.  These investigations identify the facts and root causes of the incident, and provide recommendations to help prevent a reoccurrence.  Recommended corrective actions are tracked until they are resolved.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Harcros Chemicals encourages employees to be involved in all aspects of process safety management and accident prevention.  Employees participate in process hazard analyses, incident investigations, and management of change hazard analyses.  Employees have access to all information developed as part of this prevention program and are informed of any changes in process areas.



SAFE WORK PRACTICES

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant has safe work practices that ensure the safety or our employees.  These include (1) hot work permit procedures designed to control spark of flame producing activities, (2) confined space entry permits and procedures, and (3) lockout/tagout procedures for isolating energy sources during maintenance.



CONTRACTORS

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant occasionally uses contractors for maintenance and construction.  All contractors are evaluated to ensure they are able to perform the required tasks safely.  Contractors' safety records and performance are reviewed during the selection process.  We provide training to contractors to ensure they perform work in a safe manner, are aware of the hazards of the process, understand the emergency response procedures, and report hazards they discover during their work.  We periodically monitor contractor activities to ensure they are performing their work in a safe manner.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS

A compliance audit is performed periodically to help ensure prevention activities are adequate and safety issues are addressed effectively.  Audits are performed by personnel knowledgeable in the processes but are independent of the facility.  The results of the audit are documented and recommendations are tracke

d until they are resolved.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant has safety features built into the design of the facility that help to ensure safe operations for our employees, the public and the environment.  These features may contain or control a release, detect a release, or reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes in our facility:

Automatic detection of vapors with alarms

Procedures requiring employee be present during loading and unloading operations

Release containment and control

Isolation valves

Manual shutdown systems

Diked areas to control a release

Pressure relief valves to prevent catastrophic rupture of equipment

Personal protective equipment (e.g. protective clothing, respirators)

Spill clean-up equipment.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Within the last 5-years, we have had no accidents that meet the criteria for reporting in this section.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Harcros Chemical's Dalton plant maintains a written Emergency Action Plan to protect employees, the public, and the environment.  The Plan includes information on first aid, the use of personal protective equipment, evacuation routes, and community emergency response notification.  A procedure for maintaining response equipment is also included.  Employees receive periodic training on the duties they are expected to perform during an emergency.



Our Emergency Action Plan is coordinated with local emergency responders (local Fire Department).  This includes periodic meetings with community responders so they are aware of the hazards of our processes.  Coordination and communication channels ensure the public is quickly notified, if necessary, and actions are promptly taken to minimize the consequences of a release.  We periodically conduct emergency drills so all participants are familiar with their duties dur

ing an emergency.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Harcros Chemicals Dalton plant continuously strives to improve the safety of our processes.  Suggestions for improving safety are regularly addressed through process hazard analyses, management of change procedures, incident investigations, and employee suggestions.



Improvements made since the acquisition include upgrading the toxic gas alarm warning system, installation of a new process control system, and installation of a new anhydrous ammonia storage tank.  The only specific additional safety feature planned at this time is to continue with the changeover to a more sophisticated control system to further improve the safety and efficiency of the process.  Site security has been improved in accordance with Homeland Security requirements.
